Advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) are destructive substances generated in the body when we consume refined sugars and due to environmental exposure without adequate protection. But first
column2: a bit of backstory…
column3: One of the more depressing skincare facts we can think of is how bad dietary sugar or high glycemic index foods (foods that turn to sugar almost immediately after eating them) are for almost every aspect of your skin. Chocolate cake
column7: and on and on (and we could go on and on) cause very bad things to happen to skin. UV light and air pollutants are attacking your skin from the outside in
column8: and sugar is attacking it from the inside out.
column9: What’s the relationship between sugar and AGEs? Sugars quickly and strongly bind to proteins in the skin (proteins are the main building blocks of skin) forming AGEs that progressively and continually destroy many aspects of skin
column11: the two substances that give skin its firmness and resilience. Once generated
column12: AGEs begin a cascade of progressive damage that isn’t easy to stop or reverse.
column13: Research has also shown AGEs can cause abnormal melanin production that leads to the formation of brown spots and mottled skin discolorations. Another ironic acronym for this is RAGEs
column14: meaning a receptor site for AGEs that induces unhealthy melanin production.
column15: Although sugar is certainly a major culprit in the skin-damaging creation of AGEs
column16: so is something called the Maillard Reaction (MR). The Maillard Reaction is what happens when you cook any food and brown or blacken it with high heat. That means steaming or sautéing food without browning is far healthier for your skin and body. And chargrilling foods
column18: at high heat is even worse! Our apologies to those who prefer their steaks well done.
column19: While some skincare companies claim their products contain ingredients that can block AGEs from forming
column20: that benefit hasn’t been supported anywhere in the research. In the meantime
column21: while science is working on this insidious problem
column22: eating a low sugar diet that’s rich in antioxidants
column24: and omega fatty acids is by far the best approach for younger-looking
column25: healthy skin from the inside out (and when you put those ingredients on your skin it can help from the outside in too
column26: it’s just not clear how much that helps control the visible effects of AGEs; however
column27: a huge amount of research shows those ingredients to be beneficial for skin overall).
column28: What about the occasional sweet treat? Although we can’t change what eating refined sugars does to your skin (and yes
column29: this includes so-called sugar substitutes like raw honey and agave nectar
column30: both of which the body recognizes as simple sugars)
column31: we also realize that sweets play a role in the pleasures of eating and celebrating. The trick is to keep it in moderation
column33: judicious indulgence rather than daily consumption of desserts
column36: the latter of which can contain an alarming amount of sugars.

Ascorbic acid—also known as L-ascorbic acid—has the most research of any form of vitamin C when it comes to benefits for skin. It is a potent antioxidant and skin-soothing agent that can improve the appearance of signs of aging.

column3: or when used alone in higher concentrations
column5: amounts that can be great for evening out skin tone.
column7: A particularly vulnerable antioxidant when exposed to UV light and air
column8: ascorbic acid must be packaged to protect it from these elements during routine use
column9: or its effectiveness will gradually become diminished to the point of not working at all (you will see this as oxidized discoloration
column10: meaning the product turns a copper to brownish color). For this reason
column11: avoid any vitamin C (ascorbic acid) products packaged in jars.
column12: What about using vitamin C (ascorbic acid) and niacinamide in the same product or applied at the same time in separate products?
column13: You might have read or heard that niacinamide and vitamin C shouldn’t be used at the same time
column14: whether found together in the same product or applied separately one after the other. Rest assured
column15: this combination is fine and is in fact quite beneficial!
column16: The research this misconception is based on was conducted in the 1960s; the forms of niacinamide and vitamin C used in this study were not stabilized—although niacinamide itself is very stable. The base of the formula used in this study was also far different than today’s sophisticated skincare formulas.  Today
column17: cosmetic chemists know how to combine niacinamide and vitamin C in the ideal base formulas that enhance their compatibility.
column18: The other common concern we’ve seen about combining these two ingredients has to do with the pH range. The concern is that the acidic environment ascorbic acid needs to be most effective will cause niacinamide will convert to nicotinic acid
column19: a form that can be sensitizing
column20: possibly inducing redness. Good news: This conversion process would only happen under conditions of the formula being exposed to very high heat for a long period of time. This would not apply to layering skincare products or to heat conditions that occur during manufacturing
column22:
and storage of cosmetic products that contain niacinamide and ascorbic acid.
  
What all of this means is that you can use or layer products containing both niacinamide and vitamin C knowing that they will not render each other any less effective. Each of these ingredients on its own can help to address dark spots

column8: and elimination of these sunscreen actives when small amounts enter the body via topical use. It’s important to know that the presence of this or other sunscreen actives in the body does not mean your health is at risk. Parabens are a group of controversial preservatives that include butylparaben
column2: isobutylparaben
column5: and ethylparaben. All of these were at one time the most widely used group of preservatives used in cosmetics. Parabens were so popular because of their gentle
column7: and highly effective profile in comparison to other preservatives but also because they were derived naturally from plants
column8: a rare phenomenon for a preservative. Parabens are found in plants in the form of p-hydroxybenzoic acid (PHBA)
column9: a chemical that breaks down to become parabens for a plants own protection.
column10: Over the past 10 years parabens have become criticized and condemned for use in cosmetics due to their alleged relation to health concerns affecting women and men. The research about parabens is conflicting and polarizing. Some research indicates they are safe as used in cosmetics and are preferred over other preservatives to keep a formula stable. These studies also showed parabens did not have any effect when compared to natural hormones in the body.
column12: other research has concluded they are indeed problematic: Some studies determined a 100% concentration of parabens caused skin samples (meaning not intact skin on a person) to break down. However
column13: these studies don’t apply to the tiny amount (1% or less) of parabens typically used in cosmetics. In low amounts
column14: parabens were not shown to harm skin; in fact
column15: they offer a benefit due to their ability to thwart the growth of mold
column18: Other studies casting parabens in a negative light were based on force-feeding them to rats
column19: a practice that is not only cruel but unrelated to what happens when parabens are applied to skin. There are studies indicating absorption of parabens through skin associated with application of skincare products
column20: but those studies did not take into consideration that parabens are still used as food-grade preservatives or found naturally in plants and that could have been the source not the cosmetics. We also looked at studies showing other questionable effects but those were done in vitro meaning in a petri dish or
column22: animal studies in species whose biologic makeup does not closely relate to people.
column23: We appreciate the concern about parabens and understand if people choose to avoid them. At Paula’s Choice Skincare we use parabens in a very limited number of products
column24: but that decision is based on other reasons than the scare tactics rampant on the internet. For transparency
column25: we list all ingredients on individual product pages and packaging and our Client Services team is always happy to help.

column22: lower amounts (5-10%) of capryloyl salicylic acid were shown to produce an equivalent to superior level of visible improvement compared with much greater (20-50%) concentrations of glycolic acid. Due to the natural calming properties salicylic acid has
column23: it wasn’t surprising that the LHA peels were perceived as less irritating than the AHA peel.
column24: Capryloyl salicylic acid is generally considered safe when used as directed.

column16: the CDC also stated that “Finding a measurable amount of one or more phthalate metabolites in urine does not mean that the level of one or more phthalates causes an adverse health effect. Whether phthalates at the levels of metabolites reported here are a cause for health concern is not yet known; more research is needed."
column17: Despite the negative association phthalate exposure has in animals
column18: an analysis of multiple studies and epidemiologic research led to the conclusion that “...the risks are low
column20: and that there is no convincing evidence of adverse effects on humans. Since the scientific evidence strongly suggests that risks to humans are low
column21: phthalate regulations that have been enacted are unlikely to lead to any marked improvement in public health.”

column12: but these results are short-lived and eventually give way to destruction of the substances in skin that help keep it firm. DMAE may also have skin-calming effects.

column15: the product’s pH level must be at least 10. A pH of 10 is highly alkaline

column20: in all likelihood the DMAE included in skincare products cannot have any prolonged functionality.

column2: ensulizole is a water soluble sunscreen ingredient that works in the UVB range
column3: offering no UVA protection. For this reason
column4: ensulizole should always be paired with one or more UVA-screening sunscreen actives in any SPF-rated product labeled “broad spectrum”.
column5: There’s some controversy in the research about what some refer to as ensulizole potentially being a “double-edged sword” for skin. Studies on fish scales and bat skin have shown it protects against oxidizing molecules generated by UVB exposure but it can also trigger DNA damage within skin. Although this hasn’t shown to be true on human skin
column6: it may at least partially explain why ensulizole is not commonly found in sunscreens
column7: despite having very few reports of triggering allergic reactions on human skin.
column9: ensulizole feels lighter and less oily than most synthetic sunscreen actives
column10: so is sometimes chosen when the goal is a very lightweight texture
column11: although the mineral actives titanium dioxide and zinc oxide can also feel surprisingly light on skin.
column12: Ensulizole concentrations up to 4% are approved for use in sunscreens sold in the United States
column15: and Korea. In most other parts of the world
column16: ensulizole concentrations up to 8% are permitted
column19: Along with protecting skin from UVB damage
column20: ensulizole or its salts are sometimes included in cosmetics whose clear packaging would otherwise allow the formula inside to discolor due to ongoing light exposure. Salt forms of ensulizole include potassium phenylbenzimidazole sulfonate
column21: sodium phenylbenzimidazole sulfonate and TEA-phenylbenzimidazole sulfonate.
column22: This sunscreen active is one of several currently undergoing further safety testing under the purview of the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA). This testing is to gain a better understanding of the systemic absorption
column24: and elimination of these sunscreen actives when small amounts enter the body via topical use. It’s important to know that the presence of this or other sunscreen actives in the body does not mean your health is at risk. It is anticipated that the additional testing being done will reaffirm the safety of these ingredients; however
column25: those who remain concerned can choose sunscreens with mineral actives (titanium dioxide and zinc oxide) which are not included in the FDA’s new call for additional testing.

[

Occurrence that takes place at an atomic level and is a complex physiological process. Molecules are comprised of atoms. Atoms comprise all matter. Atoms are made up of protons
column2: neutrons
column3: and electrons. Electrons occur in pairs
column4: and when an element only has a few paired electrons it can easily become unstable.
column5: Oxygen and oxides are primary examples of potential unstable elements in our environment. When oxygen interacts with skin (and because the air we breathe is 20% oxygen
column7: it almost always loses one of its electrons. This oxygen molecule
column8: which now is minus one electron
column11: the oxygen molecule quickly finds another electron
column12: and it does this by taking an electron from another molecule in the skin
column13: which is usually a healthy substance such as antioxidants in the skin. Antioxidants have lots of electrons to spare. Once those substances are robbed of all their electrons they break down and are destroyed. Oxygen molecules (or other potentially damaging environmental factors) attempting to replenish themselves in this way trigger a cascading event. The reactions that cause environmental damage take place in mere fractions of a second. Antioxidants are substances that prevent oxidative damage from beginning.
column15: The primary causes of environmental damage on skin are pollution
column19:
and solvents (such as alcohol). Antioxidants are a way to potentially neutralize these effects via topical application.

]

Parabens are a group of controversial preservatives that include butylparaben
column2: isobutylparaben
column5: and ethylparaben. All of these were at one time the most widely used group of preservatives used in cosmetics. Parabens were so popular because of their gentle
column7: and highly effective profile in comparison to other preservatives but also because they were derived naturally from plants
column8: a rare phenomenon for a preservative. Parabens are found in plants in the form of p-hydroxybenzoic acid (PHBA)
column9: a chemical that breaks down to become parabens for a plants own protection.
column10: Over the past 10 years parabens have become criticized and condemned for use in cosmetics due to their alleged relation to health concerns affecting women and men. The research about parabens is conflicting and polarizing. Some research indicates they are safe as used in cosmetics and are preferred over other preservatives to keep a formula stable. These studies also showed parabens did not have any effect when compared to natural hormones in the body.
column12: other research has concluded they are indeed problematic: Some studies determined a 100% concentration of parabens caused skin samples (meaning not intact skin on a person) to break down. However
column13: these studies don’t apply to the tiny amount (1% or less) of parabens typically used in cosmetics. In low amounts
column14: parabens were not shown to harm skin; in fact
column15: they offer a benefit due to their ability to thwart the growth of mold
column18: Other studies casting parabens in a negative light were based on force-feeding them to rats
column19: a practice that is not only cruel but unrelated to what happens when parabens are applied to skin. There are studies indicating absorption of parabens through skin associated with application of skincare products
column20: but those studies did not take into consideration that parabens are still used as food-grade preservatives or found naturally in plants and that could have been the source not the cosmetics. We also looked at studies showing other questionable effects but those were done in vitro meaning in a petri dish or
column22: animal studies in species whose biologic makeup does not closely relate to people.
column23: We appreciate the concern about parabens and understand if people choose to avoid them. At Paula’s Choice Skincare we use parabens in a very limited number of products
column24: but that decision is based on other reasons than the scare tactics rampant on the internet. For transparency
column25: we list all ingredients on individual product pages and packaging and our Client Services team is always happy to help.

Also called glycerol or glycerine
column2: glycerin is a humectant that’s present in all natural lipids (fats)
column3: whether animal or vegetable. It can be derived from natural substances by hydrolysis of fats and by fermentation of sugars; it also can be synthetically manufactured
column4: which is usually the case with modern-day skincare products.
column6: meaning it is a substance found naturally in skin

column10: and works best when combined with other replenishing and emollient ingredients.
column11: Some people wonder whether using products with glycerin takes too much water from skin when there isn’t enough humidity in the air. This can occur with pure glycerin (100% concentration—an amount that’s never used in skincare products). Any humectant (including glycerin) used in pure form can increase water loss by attracting water from the lower layers of skin into the surface layers when the climate is too arid (low humidity). For this reason
column12: glycerin and humectants are typically used in concentrations of 5% or less and always combined with other ingredients to soften skin. In fact
column13: glycerin combined with other emollients and/or oils is a fundamental cornerstone of most moisturizers.

[

Parabens are a group of controversial preservatives that include butylparaben
column2: isobutylparaben
column5: and ethylparaben. All of these were at one time the most widely used group of preservatives used in cosmetics. Parabens were so popular because of their gentle
column7: and highly effective profile in comparison to other preservatives but also because they were derived naturally from plants
column8: a rare phenomenon for a preservative. Parabens are found in plants in the form of p-hydroxybenzoic acid (PHBA)
column9: a chemical that breaks down to become parabens for a plants own protection.
column10: Over the past 10 years parabens have become criticized and condemned for use in cosmetics due to their alleged relation to health concerns affecting women and men. The research about parabens is conflicting and polarizing. Some research indicates they are safe as used in cosmetics and are preferred over other preservatives to keep a formula stable. These studies also showed parabens did not have any effect when compared to natural hormones in the body.
column12: other research has concluded they are indeed problematic: Some studies determined a 100% concentration of parabens caused skin samples (meaning not intact skin on a person) to break down. However
column13: these studies don’t apply to the tiny amount (1% or less) of parabens typically used in cosmetics. In low amounts
column14: parabens were not shown to harm skin; in fact
column15: they offer a benefit due to their ability to thwart the growth of mold
column18: Other studies casting parabens in a negative light were based on force-feeding them to rats
column19: a practice that is not only cruel but unrelated to what happens when parabens are applied to skin. There are studies indicating absorption of parabens through skin associated with application of skincare products
column20: but those studies did not take into consideration that parabens are still used as food-grade preservatives or found naturally in plants and that could have been the source not the cosmetics. We also looked at studies showing other questionable effects but those were done in vitro meaning in a petri dish or
column22: animal studies in species whose biologic makeup does not closely relate to people.
column23: We appreciate the concern about parabens and understand if people choose to avoid them. At Paula’s Choice Skincare we use parabens in a very limited number of products
column24: but that decision is based on other reasons than the scare tactics rampant on the internet. For transparency
column25: we list all ingredients on individual product pages and packaging and our Client Services team is always happy to help.

Limnanthes alba (meadowfoam) seed oil is a non-fragrant
column2: edible plant oil originally developed as an agricultural crop in the 1950s. It functions as an emollient and softening agent in skin care and hair care products.

column4: the type most resistant to rancidity when exposed to oxygen. Among plant oils
column5: meadowfoam has the highest concentration (95%) of these highly stable fatty acids
column6: making it a valuable addition to products that would otherwise be prone to spoiling quickly.
column7: Meadowfoam seed oil contains two compounds known as glucosinolate derivatives
column8: 3-methoxybenzyl isothiocyanate (MBITC) and 3-methoxyphenyl acetonitrile. Research has shown these compounds can inhibit collagen-degrading enzymes in skin and help offset the negative impact of UVB light exposure (but just to be clear
column9: these ingredients do not replace the need for broad spectrum sunscreen).
column10: The glucosinolate derivatives are not direct antioxidants (indeed
column11: meadowfoam seed oil isn’t a good source of antioxidants)
column12: but they can positively influence skin’s own antioxidant defenses
column14: Meadowfoam seed oil can also enhance the penetration of other ingredients into soil and across animal skin; however
column15: to date the same benefit hasn’t been shown to occur on human skin. On the upside
column16: the long-chain fatty acids in this plant oil have chemical similarity to some of the fatty acids found in skin’s own oil
column17: so in theory it’s certainly possible meadowfoam oil would help deliver other oil-based (lipophilic) ingredients to skin.

Parabens are a group of controversial preservatives that include butylparaben
column2: isobutylparaben
column5: and ethylparaben. All of these were at one time the most widely used group of preservatives used in cosmetics. Parabens were so popular because of their gentle
column7: and highly effective profile in comparison to other preservatives but also because they were derived naturally from plants
column8: a rare phenomenon for a preservative. Parabens are found in plants in the form of p-hydroxybenzoic acid (PHBA)
column9: a chemical that breaks down to become parabens for a plants own protection.
column10: Over the past 10 years parabens have become criticized and condemned for use in cosmetics due to their alleged relation to health concerns affecting women and men. The research about parabens is conflicting and polarizing. Some research indicates they are safe as used in cosmetics and are preferred over other preservatives to keep a formula stable. These studies also showed parabens did not have any effect when compared to natural hormones in the body.
column12: other research has concluded they are indeed problematic: Some studies determined a 100% concentration of parabens caused skin samples (meaning not intact skin on a person) to break down. However
column13: these studies don’t apply to the tiny amount (1% or less) of parabens typically used in cosmetics. In low amounts
column14: parabens were not shown to harm skin; in fact
column15: they offer a benefit due to their ability to thwart the growth of mold
column18: Other studies casting parabens in a negative light were based on force-feeding them to rats
column19: a practice that is not only cruel but unrelated to what happens when parabens are applied to skin. There are studies indicating absorption of parabens through skin associated with application of skincare products
column20: but those studies did not take into consideration that parabens are still used as food-grade preservatives or found naturally in plants and that could have been the source not the cosmetics. We also looked at studies showing other questionable effects but those were done in vitro meaning in a petri dish or
column22: animal studies in species whose biologic makeup does not closely relate to people.
column23: We appreciate the concern about parabens and understand if people choose to avoid them. At Paula’s Choice Skincare we use parabens in a very limited number of products
column24: but that decision is based on other reasons than the scare tactics rampant on the internet. For transparency
column25: we list all ingredients on individual product pages and packaging and our Client Services team is always happy to help.

column14: cosmetic chemists know how to combine niacinamide and vitamin C in the ideal base formulas that enhance their compatibility.

Parabens are a group of controversial preservatives that include butylparaben
column2: isobutylparaben
column5: and ethylparaben. All of these were at one time the most widely used group of preservatives used in cosmetics. Parabens were so popular because of their gentle
column7: and highly effective profile in comparison to other preservatives but also because they were derived naturally from plants
column8: a rare phenomenon for a preservative. Parabens are found in plants in the form of p-hydroxybenzoic acid (PHBA)
column9: a chemical that breaks down to become parabens for a plant’s own protection.
column10: Over the past 10 years parabens have become criticized and condemned for use in cosmetics due to their alleged relation to health concerns affecting women and men. The research about parabens is conflicting and polarizing. Some research indicates they are safe as used in cosmetics and are preferred over other preservatives to keep a formula stable. These studies also showed parabens did not have any effect when compared to natural hormones in the body.
column12: other research has concluded they are indeed problematic: Some studies determined a 100% concentration of parabens caused skin samples (meaning not intact skin on a person) to break down. However
column13: these studies don’t apply to the tiny amount (1% or less) of parabens typically used in cosmetics. In low amounts
column14: parabens were not shown to harm skin; in fact
column15: they offer a benefit due to their ability to thwart the growth of mold
column18: Other studies casting parabens in a negative light were based on force-feeding them to rats
column19: a practice that is not only cruel but unrelated to what happens when parabens are applied to skin. There are studies indicating absorption of parabens through skin associated with application of skincare products
column20: but those studies did not take into consideration that parabens are still used as food-grade preservatives or that they are found naturally in plants
column21: so either source could have been the origin
column22: not the cosmetics. We also looked at studies showing other questionable effects
column23: but those were done in vitro (meaning in a petri dish) or
column25: they were animal studies in species whose biologic makeup does not closely relate to people.
column26: We appreciate the concern about parabens and understand if people choose to avoid them. At Paula’s Choice Skincare we use parabens in a very limited number of products
column27: but that decision is based on other reasons than the scare tactics rampant on the internet. For transparency
column28: we list all ingredients on individual product pages and packaging and our Client Services team is always happy to help.

column8: peptides can become unstable in water-based formulas. Further
column9: because peptides are vulnerable to attack by enzymes
column10: the abundant enzymes present in skin can break the peptides down to the point where they have no effect. Knowledge of these inherent weaknesses has led many ingredient manufacturing companies to produce synthetic peptides engineered to be more stable on and within skin. Such peptides can survive intact on skin and better reach their target areas—so you’ll see anti-aging benefits!

column12: while others can improve the appearance of wrinkles
column14: and even help to soften the look of expression lines.

Phenoxyethanol is a widely used synthetic preservative that has global approval for use in all cosmetic products in concentrations up to 1%. It’s often used in even lower amounts
column2: such as when combined with other ingredients like ethylhexylglycerin. In this case
column3: lower amounts of phenoxyethanol can be just as effective as the maximum approved amount.
column4: Phenoxyethanol is incredibly versatile: It works in a large range of formulas and pH ranges
column5: has broad spectrum activity against many pathogens you don’t want multiplying in your skincare products
column7: and is compatible with many other preservatives used in cosmetics.
column8: Phenoxyethanol has become the new skincare ingredient to be demonized by various retail/natural marketing cosmetic companies and websites. The controversy is similar to the absurdity over paraben preservatives. Parabens were made evil in skincare products because of studies showing they are endocrine disruptors
column9: but parabens don’t have that property when they absorb into skin. Much like parabens
column10: phenoxyethanol being a problem in cosmetics is based on research that has nothing to do with skincare. The negative research about phenoxyethanol is not about the cosmetics-grade version. That’s a big difference. Even plant extracts have to be purified when they are removed from the ground and put into skincare products. No one wants worms
column13: and dirt in their products. Phenoxyethanol is the same situation
column14: it is purified before it is used in cosmetic formulations.
column16: concentration matters. A 100% concentration of phenoxyethanol comes with some scary warnings. For example
column17: the Safety Data Sheet on this preservative describes it as harmful if it contacts skin
column19: or gets in to the eyes. Animal studies have shown it causes reproductive and developmental toxicity—no wonder some panic is occurring! As it turns out
column20: the animal studies were about mice being fed large doses of this preservative
column21: not about it being applied to skin
column23: and then causing reproductive or developmental harm. If you fed mice mass amounts of lavender or other essential oils
column25: The rest of the alarming studies are about using phenoxyethanol in full-strength or atypically high concentrations
column26: not the amounts of 1% or less used in cosmetic products. Think of it as the difference between taking one sip of wine versus chugging several bottles at once!
column28: research has shown that compared to many other preservatives
column29: the incidence of a sensitized or allergic reaction to phenoxyethanol applied as used in cosmetics is rare. But the truth is all preservatives
column31: carry some risk of sensitizing skin. That’s because preservatives of any kind are meant to kill fungus
column33: and mold and that can negatively impact skin. Ironically
column34: in order for natural preservatives to be effective
column35: they have to be used in much higher amounts than synthetic preservatives
column36: typically up to 10%. This higher amount poses irritation and sensitizing problems for skin
column37: so natural preservatives aren’t a slam-dunk replacement for synthetics
column39: An interesting factoid: although the phenoxyethanol used in skincare products is synthetic
column40: this chemical occurs naturally in green tea
column41: just like parabens occur naturally in berries and other natural foods.

column2: propylene glycol is a humectant (hydrating) and delivery ingredient used in cosmetics.
column3: There are websites and spam e-mails stating that propylene glycol is really industrial antifreeze and that it’s the major ingredient in brake and hydraulic fluids. These sites also state that tests show it’s a strong skin sensitizer.
column4: They further point out that the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) on propylene glycol warns users to avoid skin contact. As ominous as this sounds
column5: it’s so far from the reality of cosmetics formulations that almost none of it holds any water or poses any real concern.
column7: research from toxicologists has shown that propylene glycol and similar ingredients don’t present a health risk for people when used in cosmetics.
column8: It’s important to realize that the MSDS refers to a 100% concentration of a substance. Even water and salt have frightening comments regarding their safety according to their MSDS reports.
column10: propylene glycol is used in small amounts to keep products from melting in high heat or from freezing. It also helps active ingredients penetrate skin. In the amounts used in cosmetics
column11: it’s not a concern in the least.
column12: The Cosmetic Ingredient Review Board and other groups have analyzed all of the toxicology data and exposure studies concerning topical application of propylene glycol as commonly used in cosmetics products. Their conclusion was that it is safe and does not pose a health risk to consumers.

Parabens are a group of controversial preservatives that include butylparaben
column2: isobutylparaben
column5: and ethylparaben. All of these were at one time the most widely used group of preservatives used in cosmetics. Parabens were so popular because of their gentle
column7: and highly effective profile in comparison to other preservatives but also because they were derived naturally from plants
column8: a rare phenomenon for a preservative. Parabens are found in plants in the form of p-hydroxybenzoic acid (PHBA)
column9: a chemical that breaks down to become parabens for a plants own protection.
column10: Over the past 10 years parabens have become criticized and condemned for use in cosmetics due to their alleged relation to health concerns affecting women and men. The research about parabens is conflicting and polarizing. Some research indicates they are safe as used in cosmetics and are preferred over other preservatives to keep a formula stable. These studies also showed parabens did not have any effect when compared to natural hormones in the body.
column12: other research has concluded they are indeed problematic: Some studies determined a 100% concentration of parabens caused skin samples (meaning not intact skin on a person) to break down. However
column13: these studies don’t apply to the tiny amount (1% or less) of parabens typically used in cosmetics. In low amounts
column14: parabens were not shown to harm skin; in fact
column15: they offer a benefit due to their ability to thwart the growth of mold
column18: Other studies casting parabens in a negative light were based on force-feeding them to rats
column19: a practice that is not only cruel but unrelated to what happens when parabens are applied to skin. There are studies indicating absorption of parabens through skin associated with application of skincare products
column20: but those studies did not take into consideration that parabens are still used as food-grade preservatives or found naturally in plants and that could have been the source not the cosmetics. We also looked at studies showing other questionable effects but those were done in vitro meaning in a petri dish or
column22: animal studies in species whose biologic makeup does not closely relate to people.
column23: We appreciate the concern about parabens and understand if people choose to avoid them. At Paula’s Choice Skincare we use parabens in a very limited number of products
column24: but that decision is based on other reasons than the scare tactics rampant on the internet. For transparency
column25: we list all ingredients on individual product pages and packaging and our Client Services team is always happy to help.

column9: There are numerous forms of silicones used in cosmetic products
column10: particularly leave-on skincare products and all manner of hair-care products. Common forms of silicone are cyclopentasiloxane and cyclohexasiloxane; other forms include various types of dimethicone and phenyl trimethicone.
column11: Claims that silicones in any form cause or worsen skin concerns have not been substantiated in any published research
column12: nor have reports that silicones are sensitizing to or somehow “suffocate” skin. In fact
column13: just the opposite is true which makes the misinformation difficult to understand. Almost all of the claims about silicones being problematic for skin are apparently myths or based on anecdotal evidence.
column15: they are at the same time porous and resistant though not impermeable to air. Think of silicones in a skincare formula like the covering of a tea bag. When you steep the tea bag in water the tea and all of its antioxidant properties are released into the water. Silicones remain on the surface of your skin and the other ingredients it’s mixed with “steep” through. All ingredients must be suspended in some base formula; some of the ingredients remain on the surface
column16: some are absorbed. The intent is for the “actives” to get through. The special molecular structure of silicones (large molecules with wide spaces between each molecule) allows them to form a permeable barrier and also explains why silicones rarely feel heavy or occlusive
column17: although they still offer protection against moisture loss.
column19: silicone has been shown to be helpful for offsetting dryness and flaking from common ingredients such as benzoyl peroxide.
column20: Bottom line: The types of silicones used in cosmetic products are supported by scientific research and are considered safe for consumer use. These types of cosmetic silicones are effective
column22: and versatile ingredients that benefit skin and hair in numerous ways.

column1:
[

In cosmetics
column2: this large group of ingredients is used mainly as cleansing agents in skincare and hair-care products; they include sodium lauryl sulfate
column4: and sodium laureth sulfate. Many consumers are concerned of sulfates in their cosmetics products because of widespread misinformation. Sulfates are not a problem
column5: but once organizations and companies build up fears among consumers about certain cosmetics ingredients there’s almost no going back
column7: In reality there’s absolutely no research showing that sulfates are a problem in skincare or hair-care products
column9: but that is also true for the sulfate-free cleansing agents that some cosmetics companies advertise and sell. And
column10: whether or not a cleansing agent will cause sensitivity depends on the amount of sulfate and on other ingredients present in a specific formula.
column11: Following are some of the most typical unsupported comments about sulfates: “Sulfate-free shampoos and cleansers are better for hair and skin.” No research has shown that to be even remotely the case. Sulfates are supposed to be terribly drying and damaging to hair
column12: when in fact they function no differently from the cleansing agents in sulfate-free shampoos. Almost every company that touts the fact that they don’t contain sulfates do use detergent cleansing agents such as sodium lauryl sulfoacetate
column19: Why those are supposedly any better for skin is never explained
column20: and no research is ever cited—because none exists. Sometimes these companies list those ingredients as being derived from or coming from coconut to make them sound natural and
column22: better for skin—but they all end up being primarily synthetic. That doesn’t make them bad in any way; it’s just that the claims are completely disingenuous. What you need to know is that both the sulfate-free cleansing agents and the sulfate versions can be drying and sensitizing depending on the formulation and/or your skin’s own reaction. All of these cleansing agents remove oil and the gunk from styling products
column23: which is exactly what a shampoo should do.
column24: “Sulfates in cleansers are cheap.” This one is true
column25: but so what? Lots of ingredients
column29: which has absolutely nothing to do with quality or efficacy. The first ingredient in sulfate-free shampoos is water (about 90% water) and no other cosmetic ingredient is cheaper than that!
column30: “Sulfates are used in floor cleaners and are corrosive.” This can be true
column31: when used in large amounts and when left on surfaces over time
column32: but so what? Salt is used to melt ice on the roadway
column34: which doesn’t make salt bad; it just depends on how much you use and how long you leave it on something. This is also true for the alternative sulfate-free shampoos and cleansers as well; they can also be corrosive over time depending on how much is used and how long it is left on.
column35: “Sulfates can be sensitizing.” This can absolutely be true
column37: so what? As a general category
column38: sulfates are not sensitizing when used in appropriate amounts in shampoos and cleansers and the same is true for sulfate-free alternative cleansing agents. All of the research about sulfates being sensitizing are from patch tests where a concentration is left on skin under a bandage for 24 hours
column39: which is not how a cleanser or shampoo is used. Sodium lauryl sulfate is considered one of the more sensitizing cleansing agents and we recommend avoiding it when it is high up on the ingredient list
column40: but that’s NOT because it’s a sulfate; rather
column41:
it’s because of its interaction with skin.

]

Naturally occurring mineral composed of magnesium
column2: hydrogen
column4: and silicon which combine to form what’s known as anhydrous (contains no water) magnesium silicate. Talc is often the main ingredient in loose and pressed face powders
column6: and body powders for adults and children. It may also be used in skin care products where it serves as an absorbent. Talc is also used in some liquid foundations and concealers
column7: where it adds opacity and contributes to the makeup’s texture.
column8: An ongoing concern with talc since the 1970s has been whether it contains asbestos fibers known as chrysotile
column9: which pose a serious risk to lung health when inhaled. Talc can become contaminated with these fibers during the mining process because asbestos (also a naturally-occurring mineral) is found in nature in close proximity to talc. This is why the selection of talc mining sites is so important
column10: as is screening all talc batches for the presence of asbestos fibers.
column11: The screening process mentioned above is something the United States Food & Drug Administration (FDA) has been actively doing with commercially-available talc-containing products for several years. They’re routinely announcing to the public which talc-containing products do and do not contain asbestos. Thankfully
column12: the majority of such products do not contain this carcinogen and are considered safe when used as directed. Talc-containing products that testing shows do have asbestos are routinely recalled. This includes talc-based body powders from major brands like Johnson & Johnson
column13: who’ve been subject to ongoing litigation concerning allegations of the presence of asbestos in their talc products.
column14: Consumers who remain concerned about whether the talc-containing products they use contain asbestos are advised to contact the brand and ask about batch certification testing to ensure the safety of these products. But we must acknowledge the public record the talc industry at large has of providing misleading information in order to conceal potential risk
column17: you may wish to avoid all personal care products that contain talc and seek alternatives such as those made with other absorbents like corn starch
column25: despite ongoing controversies and legal issues
column26: asbestos-free talc is considered safe for use in makeup and skin care
column27: although it’s recommended to avoid applying loose powder talc in the genital area. According to the formal safety assessment completed in 2015
column28: “Industry specifications state that cosmetic-grade talc must contain no detectable fibrous
column29: asbestos minerals.” They go on to caution that “Talc should not be applied to the skin when the epidermal barrier is missing or significantly disrupted”
column30: which makes sense given talc is not meant to get into the body
column31: it is meant to stay on skin’s surface.
